Before he was the swaggering, stadium-packing megastar, Bruce Springsteen was a brooding introvert, desperate to strike a 

balance between his nuanced songwriting and the heft of his backing band. Clinton HeylinÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s revelatory biography, E Street 

Shuffle, chronicles the evolution and influence of SpringsteenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s E Street Band as they rose from blue-collar New Jersey 

to the heights of rock stardom. The bandÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s playersÃ¢â‚¬â€most notably saxophonist Clarence Ã¢â‚¬Å“Big ManÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ Clemons, guitarist 

Ã¢â‚¬Å“LittleÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ Stevie Van Zandt, and drummer Max WeinbergÃ¢â‚¬â€became SpringsteenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s comrades in concert, helping him find the 

elusive sound and sonic punch that highlighted The BossÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s most creative period, including Darkness on the Edge of Town,

Band to pursue projects like the eerie acoustic of Nebraska. Coinciding with the forteith anniversary of SpringsteenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s
